Award.AwardTitle: Laboratory Simulation Studies of EUV-VUV Photolysis of Cosmic Ice Analogs
Award.AbstractNarration: The surfaces of icy Solar System bodies are predominantly water ice, with small amounts of methane, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, nitrogen, and ammonia. The outer surfaces are constantly subject to photon irradiation and particle bombardment, the solar wind, cosmic rays, and chemical reactions on surfaces, in addition to thermal cycling. In this project, the collaborating team will continue, with renewed NSF support, their laboratory experiments on the physics of extreme ultraviolet (EUV)-vacuum ultraviolet (VUV) photolysis of cosmic ice analogs. They plan simultaneous investigations of photon-induced chemical reactions and photodesorption in ice analogs containing water and other relevant species. A tunable intense synchrotron radiation light source available at the National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center (NSRRC), Taiwan, will provide the required EUV-VUV photons. The team will identify the type of molecules that form in the ice samples, and those that come off the ice surfaces, quantify their production yields, understand their production mechanisms, the destruction yields (lifetimes or stabilities) of the parent ice molecule(s), and ascertain their significance in astronomical environments. Much of the sophisticated equipment and advanced experimental techniques required for the proposed work have been developed by the team with prior NSF funding. The results will be particularly relevant to understanding of the water-rich icy satellites of the giant planets, comets, the interstellar medium, molecular clouds, and protostellar regions. The research results will also be incorporated into teaching materials for advanced undergraduate and graduate courses. The project will train a postdoctoral associate and a graduate student, with an emphasis on working with a synchrotron radiation facility.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF funded project allows us to address fundamental spectroscopic properties of ice samples, photodesorption yields, photon-induced chemical processes, and yields of photolyzed products and their stabilities in order to interpret astronomical observations. The NSF funding has partially supported the development of the state-of-the-art experimental apparatus, which has been equipped with an ultrahigh vacuum sample chambers, a Fourier-Transform Infrared Spectrometer (FTIR), a Quadrupole Mass Spectrometer (QMS), and a gold-coated Quartz Crystal Microbalance (QCM). The setup of these advanced experimental instruments requires expertise of several different academic trainings. In fact, this is the first experimental facility in the world that it permits a given ice system to be simultaneously investigated by employing four diversified instruments in an identical experimental apparatus and identical experimental procedures and conditions in the very same laboratory. Our integrated apparatus has apparently been regarded as a standard means in the research field of ice photochemistry community. The Principal Investigator has developed an ongoing collaboration with the National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Taiwan, to use the synchrotron radiation light sources covering from vacuum ultraviolet (VUV), extreme ultraviolet (EUV), to the soft X-ray regions to enable the required measurements.

We have carried out studies on photon irradiation of pure ices including N2, CO and CO ices, and ice mixtures including N2:CH4, N2:C2H2, H2O:pyrimidine, CO:H2S, CO2:H2S, H2O:CO2:NH3, C10H8:H2O:NH3 ices at low temperatures. Here we just mention a few exciting results obtained so far. For example, we have demonstrated that complex amino acids can be produced through photolysis of ice mixtures consisting of (1) only inorganic compounds, namely, an ice sample made of H2O, CO2, and NH3 molecules at 16 K and (2) organic naphthalene C10H8 mixed in a H2O:NH3 ice mixtures at 15 K. Naphthalene is the smallest polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH). The quantum yields for producing several amino acids have been determined to be of the order of 10-6. This may supports a scenario where molecules of biological interest could be formed in many different astrophysical environments before being delivered to the early Earth by meteorites. As another example, we note that the prominent 2044 cm-1 feature of OCS at 20 K shifts to 2040 cm-1 after warming up the VUV irradiated CO:H2S (20:1) ice residues to 30 K. The spectral position of OCS appears to agree well with the 2041 cm-1 feature of OCS observed toward the W33A and AFGL 989 protostellar sources. Thus, the present laboratory results could provide additional information to possibly support the model of estimated abundance ratio of CO/OCS in the protostellar regions. Furthermore, we detect heavy S-bearing compounds during the warm-up process of the photolyzed residues of CO:H2S ice mixtures. The presence of S-polymers in dust ice grains could possibly account for the missing sulfur in dense cloud and circumstellar environments. As a last example, we have demonstrated for the first time that we can measure the absolute partial desorption yields for C, O, CO, O2 and CO2 species from photolysis of CO ice and CO2 ice. The work will provide results for further fundamental understanding of electron correlations and competing processes for decaying channels in molecular solid physics.
